revision.comment: Alter: last2, last3, title, template type. Add: class, eprint, issue, pmc, doi, year, pages, volume, pmid, journal, date. Removed parameters. Formatted [[WP:ENDASH|dashes]]. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
In planetary science a '''streaming instability''' is a hypothetical mechanism for the formation of [[planetesimal]]s in which the drag felt by solid particles orbiting in a gas disk leads to their spontaneous concentration into clumps which can gravitationally collapse.<ref name=Lund_2012>{{cite web|title=Planetesimal formation|url=http://www.astro.lu.se/Research/OTA/TAgroup/planetesimals.shtml|publisher=Lund University|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> Small initial clumps increase the orbital velocity of the gas, slowing radial drift locally, leading to their growth as they are joined by faster drifting isolated particles. Massive filaments form that reach densities sufficient for the gravitational collapse into planetesimals the size of large asteroids, bypassing a number of barriers to the traditional formation mechanisms. The formation of streaming instabilities requires solids that are moderately coupled to the gas and a local solid to gas ratio of one or greater. The growth of solids large enough to become moderately coupled to the gas is more likely outside the ice line and in regions with limited turbulence. An initial concentration of solids with respect to the gas is necessary to suppress turbulence sufficiently to allow the solid to gas ratio to reach greater than one at the mid-plane. A wide variety of mechanisms to selectively remove gas or to concentrate solids have been proposed. In the inner Solar System the formation of streaming instabilities requires a greater initial concentration of solids or the growth of solid beyond the size of chondrules.<ref name="Johansen_Jacquet_2015" />
==Background== Planetesimals and larger bodies are traditionally thought to have formed via a hierarchical accretion, the formation of large objects via the collision and mergers of small objects. This process begins with the collision of [[cosmic dust|dust]] due to [[Brownian motion]] producing larger aggregates held together by [[van der Waals force]]s. The aggregates settle toward the mid-plane of the disk and collide due to gas turbulence forming pebbles and larger objects. Further collisions and mergers eventually yield planetesimals 1–10 km in diameter held together by self-gravity. The growth of the largest planetesimals then accelerates, as gravitational focusing increases their effective cross-section, resulting in runaway [[Nebular hypothesis#Rocky planets|accretion]] forming the larger [[asteroid]]s. Later, gravitational scattering by the larger objects excites relative motions, causing a transition to slower oligarchic accretion that ends with the formation of planetary embryos. In the outer Solar System the planetary embryos grow large enough to accrete gas, forming the giant planets. In the inner Solar System the orbits of the planetary embryos become unstable, leading to giant impacts and the formation of the terrestrial planets.<ref name="Morbidelli_etal_2009" />
A number of obstacles to this process have been identified: barriers to growth via collisions, the radial drift of larger solids, and the turbulent stirring of planetesimals.<ref name="Johansen_Jacquet_2015" /> As a particle grows the time required for its motion to react to changes in the motion of the gas in turbulent eddies increases. The relative motions of particles, and collision velocities, therefore increases as with the mass of the particles. For [[Silicate#Silicate rock and minerals|silicates]] the increased collision velocities cause dust aggregates to compact into solid particles that bounce rather than stick, ending growth at the size of [[chondrule]]s, roughly 1 mm in diameter.<ref name="Zsom_etal_2010">{{cite journal|last1=Zsom|first1=A.|last2=Ormel|first2=C. W.|last3=Güttler|first3=C.|last4=Blum|first4=J.|last5=Dullemond|first5=C. P.|title=The outcome of protoplanetary dust growth: pebbles, boulders, or planetesimals? II. Introducing the bouncing barrier|journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics|date=2010|volume=513|page=A57|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/200912976|arxiv=1001.0488|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2010/05/aa12976-09/aa12976-09.html|bibcode = 2010A&A...513A..57Z }}</ref><ref name="Kuffmeier_2016">{{cite web|last1=Küffmeier|first1=Michael|title=The bouncing barrier of silicates and ices|url=https://astrobites.org/2016/01/27/the-bouncing-barrier-of-silicates-and-ices/|website=astrobites|accessdate=4 December 2016|date=2016-01-27}}</ref> Icy solids may not be affected by the bouncing barrier but their growth can be halted at larger sizes due to fragmentation as collision velocities increase.<ref name="Drazkowska_Dullemond_2014" /> Radial drift is the result of the pressure support of the gas, enabling it to orbit at a slower velocity than the solids. Solids orbiting through this gas lose angular momentum and spiral toward the central [[star]] at rates that increase as they grow. At 1 AU this produces a meter-sized barrier, with the rapid loss of large objects in as little as ~1000 orbits, ending with their vaporization as they approach too close to the star.<ref name="Protostars_and Planets_2014">{{cite book |last1=Johansen |first1=A. |last2=Blum |first2=J. |last3=Tanaka |first3=H. |last4=Ormel |first4=C. |last5=Bizzarro |first5=M. |last6=Rickman |first6=H. |date=2014 |chapter=The Multifaceted Planetesimal Formation Process |editor1-last=Beuther |editor1-first=H. |editor2-last=Klessen |editor2-first=R. S. |editor3-last=Dullemond |editor3-first=C. P. |editor4-last=Henning |editor4-first=T. |title=Protostars and Planets VI |journal=Protostars and Planets Vi |pages=547–570 |publisher=University of Arizona Press |arxiv=1402.1344 |bibcode=2014prpl.conf..547J |doi=10.2458/azu_uapress_9780816531240-ch024 |isbn=978-0-8165-3124-0}}</ref><ref name="Kuffmeier_2015">{{cite web|last1=Küffmeier|first1=Michael|title=What is the meter size barrier?|url=https://astrobites.org/2015/04/03/what-is-the-meter-size-barrier/|website=astrobites|accessdate=3 December 2016|date=2015-04-03}}</ref> At greater distances the growth of icy bodies can become drift limited at smaller sizes when their drift timescales become shorter than their growth timescales.<ref name="Birnstiel_etal_2016" /> [[Turbulence]] in the protoplanetary disk can create density fluctuations which exert torques on planetesimals exciting their relative velocities. Outside the dead zone the higher random velocities can result in the destruction of smaller planetesimals, and the delay of the onset of runaway growth until planetesimals reach radii of 100 km.<ref name=Johansen_Jacquet_2015>{{cite book |last1=Johansen |first1=A. |last2=Jacquet |first2=E. |last3=Cuzzi |first3=J. N. |last4=Morbidelli |first4=A. |last5=Gounelle |first5=M. |date=2015 |chapter=New Paradigms For Asteroid Formation |editor1-last=Michel |editor1-first=P. |editor2-last=DeMeo |editor2-first=F. |editor3-last=Bottke |editor3-first=W. |title=Asteroids IV |pages=471 |publisher=University of Arizona Press |series=Space Science Series |arxiv=1505.02941 |bibcode=2015aste.book..471J |isbn=978-0-8165-3213-1|doi=10.2458/azu_uapress_9780816532131-ch025 }}</ref>
Some evidence exists that planetesimal formation may have bypassed these barriers to incremental growth. In the inner asteroid belt all of the low albedo asteroids that have not been identified as part of a collisional family are larger than 35 km.<ref name="Delbo_etal">{{cite journal|last1=Delbo’|first1=Marco|last2=Walsh|first2=Kevin|last3=Bolin|first3=Bryce|last4=Avdellidou|first4=Chrysa|last5=Morbidelli|first5=Alessandro|title=Identification of a primordial asteroid family constrains the original planetesimal population|journal=Science|volume=357|issue=6355|pages=1026–1029|date=2017|doi=10.1126/science.aam6036|pmid=28775212|bibcode=2017Sci...357.1026D}}</ref><ref name="Temming_2017">{{cite web|last1=Temming|first1=Maria|title=The solar system's earliest asteroids may have all been massive|url=https://www.sciencenews.org/article/solar-systems-earliest-asteroids-may-have-all-been-massive|website=ScienceNews|accessdate=5 August 2017}}</ref> A change in the slope of the size distribution of asteroids at roughly 100 km can be reproduced in models if the minimal diameter of the planetesimals was 100 km and the smaller asteroids are debris from collisions.<ref name="Morbidelli_etal_2009">{{cite journal|last1=Morbidelli|first1=Alessandro|last2=Bottke|first2=William F.|last3=Nesvorný|first3=David|last4=Levison|first4=Harold F.|title=Asteroids were born big|journal=Icarus|date=2009|volume=204|issue=2|pages=558–573|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2009.07.011|arxiv=0907.2512|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103509003029|bibcode = 2009Icar..204..558M }}</ref><ref name="Beatty_2009">{{cite web|last1=Beatty|first1=Kelly|title=Were Asteroids Born Big?|url=http://www.skyandtelescope.com/astronomy-news/were-asteroids-born-big/|website=Sky & Telescope|accessdate=3 December 2016|date=2009-08-25}}</ref> A similar change in slope has been observed in the size distribution of the [[Kuiper belt]] objects.<ref name="Fraser_etal_2014">{{cite journal|last1=Fraser|first1=Wesley C.|last2=Brown|first2=Michael E.|last3=Morbidelli|first3=Alessandro|last4=Parker|first4=Alex|last5=Batygin|first5=Konstantin|title=The Absolute Magnitude Distribution of Kuiper Belt Objects|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2014|volume=782|issue=2|page=100|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/782/2/100|arxiv=1401.2157|bibcode = 2014ApJ...782..100F }}</ref><ref name="Francis_2015">{{cite web|last1=Francis|first1=Matthew|title=Some Planet-like Kuiper Belt Objects Don't Play "Nice"|url=http://www.universetoday.com/108189/some-planet-like-kuiper-belt-objects-dont-play-nice/|website=UniverseToday|accessdate=4 December 2016|date=2014-01-16}}</ref> The low numbers of small craters on [[Pluto]]<ref name="Robbins_etal_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Robbins|first1=Stuart J.|last2=and 28 others|title=Craters of the Pluto-Charon system|journal=Icarus|date=2017|volume=287|pages=187–206|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2016.09.027|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103516306133?via%3Dihub|bibcode=2017Icar..287..187R}}</ref> has also been cited as evidence the largest KBO's formed directly.<ref name=New_Horizons_2015>{{cite web|title=At Pluto, New Horizons Finds Geology of All Ages, Possible Ice Volcanoes, Insight into Planetary Origins|url=http://pluto.jhuapl.edu/News-Center/News-Article.php?page=20151109|publisher=The Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory LLC|accessdate=3 January 2016}}</ref> Furthermore, if the cold classical KBO's formed in situ from a low mass disk, as suggested by the presence of loosely bound binaries,<ref name="Atkinson_2010">{{cite web|last1=Atkinson|first1=Nancy|title=Neptune Acquitted on One Count of Harassment|url=http://www.universetoday.com/75074/neptune-acquitted-on-one-count-of-harassment/|website=Universe Today|accessdate=3 December 2016|date=2010-10-05}}</ref> they are unlikely to have formed via the traditional mechanism.<ref name="Parker_etal_2011">{{cite journal|last1=Parker|first1=Alex H.|last2=Kavelaars|first2=J. J.|last3=Petit|first3=Jean-Marc|last4=Jones|first4=Lynne|last5=Gladman|first5=Brett|last6=Parker|first6=Joel|title=Characterization of Seven Ultra-wide Trans-Neptunian Binaries|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2011|volume=743|issue=1|page=1|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/743/1/1|bibcode=2011ApJ...743....1P|arxiv = 1108.2505 }}</ref> The dust activity of [[comet]]s indicates a low tensile strength that would be the result of a gentle formation process with collisions at [[free-fall]] velocities.<ref name="Blum_etal_2014">{{cite journal|last1=Blum|first1=J.|last2=Gundlach|first2=B.|last3=Mühle|first3=S.|last4=Trigo-Rodriguez|first4=J. M.|title=Comets formed in solar-nebula instabilities! - An experimental and modeling attempt to relate the activity of comets to their formation process|journal=Icarus|date=2014|volume=235|pages=156–169|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2014.03.016|arxiv=1403.2610|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103514001420|bibcode=2014Icar..235..156B}}</ref><ref name="Blum_etal_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Blum|first1=Jürgen|last2=et al|title=Evidence for the formation of comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko through gravitational collapse of a bound clump of pebbles|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|volume=469|pages=S755–S773|arxiv=1710.07846|year=2017|doi=10.1093/mnras/stx2741}}</ref>
==Description== Streaming instabilities, first described by Andrew Youdin and Jeremy Goodman,<ref name="Youdin_Goodman_2005">{{cite journal|last1=Youdin|first1=Andrew|last2=Goodman|first2=Jeremy|title=Streaming Instabilities in Protoplanetary Disks|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2005|volume=620|issue=1|pages=459–469|doi=10.1086/426895|arxiv = astro-ph/0409263 |bibcode = 2005ApJ...620..459Y }}</ref> are driven by differences in the motions of the gas and solid particles in the [[protoplanetary disk]]. The gas is hotter and denser closer to the star, creating a pressure gradient that partially offsets gravity from the star. The partial support of the pressure gradient allows the gas to orbit at roughly 50 m/s below the [[orbital speed|Keplerian velocity]] at its distance. The solid particles, however, are not supported by the pressure gradient and would orbit at Keplerian velocities in the absence of the gas. The difference in velocities results in a headwind that causes the solid particles to spiral toward the central star as they lose momentum to [[aerodynamic drag]]. The drag also produces a back [[reaction (physics)|reaction]] on the gas, increasing its velocity. When solid particles cluster in the gas, the reaction reduces the headwind locally, allowing the cluster to orbit faster and undergo less inward drift. The slower drifting clusters are overtaken and joined by isolated particles, increasing the local density and further reducing radial drift, fueling an [[exponential growth]] of the initial clusters.<ref name="Johansen_Jacquet_2015" /> In simulations the clusters form massive filaments that can grow or dissipate, and that can collide and merge or split into multiple filaments. The separation of filaments averages 0.2 gas [[scale height]]s, roughly 0.02 [[astronomical unit|AU]] at the distance of the asteroid belt.<ref name=Yan_Johansen_2014>{{cite journal |last1=Yang |first1=C.-C. |last2=Johansen |first2=A. |date=2014 |title=On the Feeding Zone of Planetesimal Formation by the Streaming Instability |journal=The Astrophysical Journal |volume=792 |issue=2 |page=86 |arxiv=1407.5995 |bibcode=2014ApJ...792...86Y |doi=10.1088/0004-637X/792/2/86}}</ref> The densities of the filaments can exceed a thousand times the gas density, sufficient to trigger the gravitational collapse and fragmentation of the filaments into bound clusters.<ref name="Johansen_etal_2012" />
The clusters shrink as energy is dissipated by gas drag and [[inelastic collision]]s, leading to the formation of planetesimals the size of large asteroids.<ref name=Johansen_etal_2012>{{cite journal |last1=Johansen |first1=A. |last2=Youdin |first2=A. N. |last3=Lithwick |first3=Y. |date=2012 |title=Adding particle collisions to the formation of asteroids and Kuiper belt objects via streaming instabilities |url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2012/01/aa17701-11.pdf |journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics |volume=537 |page=A125 |arxiv=1111.0221 |bibcode=2012A&A...537A.125J |doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201117701}}</ref> Impact speeds are limited during the collapse of the smaller clusters that form 1–10 km asteroids, reducing the fragmentation of particles, leading to the formation of porous [[chondrite|pebble pile]] planetesimals with low densities.<ref name="Wahlberg Jansson_2014">{{cite journal |last1=Wahlberg Jansson |first1=K. |last2=Johansen |first2=A. |date=2014 |title=Formation of pebble-pile planetesimals |url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2014/10/aa24369-14.pdf |journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics |volume=570 |page=A47 |arxiv=1408.2535 |bibcode=2014A&A...570A..47W |doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201424369}}</ref> Gas drag slows the fall of the smallest particles and less frequent collisions slows the fall of the largest particles during this process, resulting in the size sorting of particles with mid-sized particles forming a porous core and a mix of particle sizes forming denser outer layers.<ref name="Wahlberg Jansson_Johansen_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Wahlberg Jansson|first1=Karl|last2=Johansen|first2=Anders|title=Radially resolved simulations of collapsing pebble clouds in protoplanetary discs|date=2017|arxiv=1706.03655|doi=10.1093/mnras/stx1470|volume=469|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|pages=S149–S157|bibcode = 2017MNRAS.469S.149W }}</ref> The impact speeds and the fragmentation of particles increase with the mass of the clusters, lowering the [[porosity]] and increasing the density of the larger objects such as 100 km asteroid that form from a mixture of pebbles and pebble fragments.<ref name="Wahlberg Jansson_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Wahlberg Jansson|first1=Karl|last2=Johansen|first2=Anders|last3=Bukhari Syed|first3=Mohtashim|last4=Blum|first4=Jürgen|title=The role of pebble fragmentation in planetesimal formation II. Numerical simulations|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2016|volume=835|issue=1|page=109|arxiv=1609.07052|doi=10.3847/1538-4357/835/1/109|bibcode = 2017ApJ...835..109W }}</ref> Collapsing swarms with excess [[angular momentum]] can fragment, forming [[Binary asteroid|binary]] or in some cases trinary objects resembling those in the Kuiper belt.<ref name=Nesvorny_2010>{{cite journal |last1=Nesvorný |first1=D. |last2=Youdin |first2=A. N. |last3=Richardson |first3=D. C. |date=2010 |title=Formation of Kuiper Belt Binaries by Gravitational Collapse |journal=The Astronomical Journal |volume=140 |issue=3 |pages=785–793 |arxiv=1007.1465 |bibcode=2010AJ....140..785N |doi=10.1088/0004-6256/140/3/785}}</ref> In simulations the initial mass distribution of the planetesimals formed via streaming instabilities fits a power law: dn/dM ~ M<sup>−1.6</sup>,<ref name="Simon_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Simon|first1=Jacob B.|last2=Armitage|first2=Philip J.|last3=Li|first3=Rixin|last4=Youdin|first4=Andrew N.|title=The Mass and Size Distribution of Planetesimals Formed by the Streaming Instability. I. The Role of Self-gravity|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2016|volume=822|issue=1|page=55|doi=10.3847/0004-637X/822/1/55|arxiv=1512.00009|bibcode = 2016ApJ...822...55S }}</ref><ref name="Simon_etal_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Simon|first1=Jacob B.|last2=Armitage|first2=Philip J.|last3=Youdin|first3=Andrew N.|last4=Li|first4=Rixin|title=Evidence for universality in the initial planetesimal mass function|journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters|date=2017| volume=847|issue=2|page=L12|arxiv=1705.03889|bibcode=2017ApJ...847L..12S|doi=10.3847/2041-8213/aa8c79}}</ref> that is slightly steeper than that of small asteroids,<ref name="Tsirvoulis_etal_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Tsirvoulis|first1=Georgios|last2=Morbidelli|first2=Alessandro|last3=Delbo|first3=Marco|last4=Tsiganis|first4=Kleomenis|title=Reconstructing the size distribution of the primordial Main Belt|date=2017|arxiv=1706.02091|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2017.05.026|journal=Icarus|volume=34|pages=14–23|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103516308119|bibcode=2018Icar..304...14T}}</ref> with an exponential cutoff at larger masses.<ref name="Johansen_Mac-Low_etal_2015" /><ref name="Schafer_etal_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Schäfer|first1=Urs|last2=Yang|first2=Chao-Chin|last3=Johansen|first3=Anders|title=Initial mass function of planetesimals formed by the streaming instability|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2017|volume=597|page=A69|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201629561|arxiv=1611.02285|url=https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2017/01/aa29561-16/aa29561-16.html|bibcode=2017A&A...597A..69S}}</ref> Continued accretion of [[chondrule]]s from the disk may shift the size distribution of the largest objects toward that of the current asteroid belt.<ref name="Johansen_Mac-Low_etal_2015">{{cite journal|last1=Johansen|first1=Anders|last2=Mac Low|first2=Mordecai-Mark|last3=Lacerda|first3=Pedro|last4=Bizzarro|first4=Martin|title=Growth of asteroids, planetary embryos, and Kuiper belt objects by chondrule accretion|journal=Science Advances|date=2015|volume=1|issue=3|page=1500109|doi=10.1126/sciadv.1500109|pmid=26601169|pmc=4640629|url=http://advances.sciencemag.org/content/1/3/e1500109|arxiv = 1503.07347 |bibcode = 2015SciA....1E0109J }}</ref> In the [[outer solar system|outer Solar System]] the largest objects can continue to grow via [[pebble accretion]], possibly forming the [[Planetary core|cores]] of [[giant planets]].<ref name=Lambrechts_Johansen_2012>{{cite journal|last1=Lambrechts|first1=M.|last2=Johansen|first2=A.|title=Rapid growth of gas-giant cores by pebble accretion|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2012|volume=544|page=A32|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201219127|arxiv=1205.3030|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2012/08/aa19127-12/aa19127-12.html|bibcode = 2012A&A...544A..32L }}</ref>
==Requirements== Streaming instabilities form only in the presence of rotation and the radial drift of solids. The initial linear phase of a streaming instability,<ref name="Armitage_2015">{{cite document|last1=Armitage|first1=Philip J.|title=Physical processes in protoplanetary disks|arxiv=1509.06382|work=From Protoplanetary Disks to Planet Formation|publisher=45th Saas-Fee Advanced Course|bibcode=2015arXiv150906382A|year=2015}}</ref> begins with a transient region of high pressure within the protoplanetary disk. The elevated pressure alters the local pressure gradient supporting the gas, reducing the gradient on the region's inner edge and increasing the gradient on the region's outer edge. The gas therefore must orbit faster near the inner edge and is able to orbit slower near the outer edge.<ref name=Johansen_etal_2007>{{cite journal |last1=Johansen |first1=A. |last2=Oishi |first2=J. S. |last3=Mac Low |first3=M.-M. |last4=Klahr |first4=H. |last5=Henning |first5=T. |last6=Youdin |first6=A. |date=2007 |title=Rapid planetesimal formation in turbulent circumstellar disks |journal=Nature |volume=448 |issue=7157 |pages=1022–1025 |arxiv=0708.3890 |bibcode=2007Natur.448.1022J |doi=10.1038/nature06086 |pmid=17728751}}</ref> The [[Coriolis force]]s resulting from these relative motions support the elevated pressure, creating a [[geostrophic wind|geostropic balance]].<ref name="Jacquet_etal_2011">{{cite journal|last1=Jacquet|first1=Emmanuel|last2=Balbus|first2=Steven|last3=Latter|first3=Henrik|title=On linear dust-gas streaming instabilities in protoplanetary discs|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|date=2011|volume=415|issue=4|pages=3591–3598|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18971.x|arxiv=1104.5396|url=http://mnras.oxfordjournals.org/content/415/4/3591|bibcode = 2011MNRAS.415.3591J }}</ref> The motions of the solids near the high pressure regions are also affected: solids at its outer edge face a greater headwind and undergo faster radial drift, solids at its inner edge face a lesser headwind and undergo a slower radial drift.<ref name="Johansen_etal_2007" /> This differential radial drift produces a buildup of solids in higher pressure regions. The drag felt by the solids moving toward the region also creates a back reaction on the gas that reinforces the elevated pressure leading to a runaway process.<ref name="Jacquet_etal_2011" /> As more solids are carried toward the region by radial drift this eventually yields a concentration of solids sufficient to drive the increase of the velocity of the gas and reduce the local radial drift of solids seen in streaming instabilities.<ref name="Johansen_etal_2007" />
Streaming instabilities form when the solid particles are moderately coupled to the gas, with [[Stokes number]]s of 0.01 - 3; the local solid to gas ratio is near or larger than 1; and the vertically integrated solid to gas ratio is a few times Solar.<ref name=Krijt_etal_2016>{{cite journal |last1=Krijt |first1=S. |last2=Ormel |first2=C. W. |last3=Dominik |first3=C. |last4=Tielens |first4=A. G. G. M. |date=2016 |title=A panoptic model for planetesimal formation and pebble delivery |journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics |volume=586 |issue= |pages=A20 |arxiv=1511.07762 |bibcode=2016A&A...586A..20K |url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2016/02/aa27533-15/aa27533-15.html|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201527533}}</ref> The Stokes number is a measure of the relative influences of inertia and gas drag on a particle's motion. In this context it is the product of the timescale for the [[exponential decay]] of a particle's velocity due to drag and the [[angular frequency]] of its orbit. Small particles like dust are strongly coupled and move with the gas, large bodies such as planetesimals are weakly coupled and orbit largely unaffected by the gas.<ref name="Birnstiel_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Birnstiel|first1=T.|last2=Fang|first2=M.|last3=Johansen|first3=A.|title=Dust Evolution and the Formation of Planetesimals|journal=Space Science Reviews|date=2016|doi=10.1007/s11214-016-0256-1|arxiv=1604.02952|volume=205|issue=1–4|pages=41–75|bibcode = 2016SSRv..205...41B }}</ref> Moderately coupled solids, sometimes referred to as pebbles, range from roughly cm- to m-sized at asteroid belt distances and from mm- to dm-sized beyond 10 AU.<ref name="Protostars_and Planets_2014" /> These objects orbit through the gas like planetesimals but are slowed due to the headwind and undergo significant radial drift. The moderately coupled solids that participate in streaming instabilities are those dynamically affected by changes in the motions of gas on scales similar to those of the Coriolis effect, allowing them to be captured by regions of high pressure in a rotating disk.<ref name="Johansen_Jacquet_2015" /> Moderately coupled solids also retain influence on the motion of the gas. If the local solid to gas ratio is near or above 1, this influence is strong enough to reinforce regions of high pressure and to increase the orbital velocity of the gas and slow radial drift.<ref name="Jacquet_etal_2011" /> Reaching and maintaining this local solid to gas at the mid-plane requires an average solid to gas ratio in a vertical cross section of the disk that is a few times solar.<ref name=Drazkowska_Dullemond_2014>{{cite journal |last1=Drążkowska |first1=J. |last2=Dullemond |first2=C. P. |date=2014 |title=Can dust coagulation trigger streaming instability? |url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2014/12/aa24809-14.pdf |journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics |volume=572 |page=A78 |arxiv=1410.3832 |bibcode=2014A&A...572A..78D |doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201424809}}</ref> When the average solid to gas ratio is 0.01, roughly that estimated from measurements of the current Solar System, turbulence at the mid-plane generates a wavelike pattern that puffs up the mid-plane layer of solids. This reduces the solid to gas ratio at the mid-plane to less than 1, suppressing the formation of dense clumps. At higher average solid to gas ratios the mass of solids dampens this turbulence allowing a thin mid-plane layer to form.<ref name="Johansen_etal_2009">{{cite journal|last1=Johansen|first1=Anders|last2=Youdin|first2=Andrew|last3=Mac Low|first3=Mordecai-Mark|title=Particle Clumping and Planetesimal Formation Depend Strongly on Metallicity|journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters|date=2009|volume=704|issue=2|pages=L75–L79|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/704/2/L75|arxiv=0909.0259|bibcode=2009ApJ...704L..75J}}</ref> Stars with higher metallicities are more likely to reach the minimum solid to gas ratio making them favorable locations for planetesimal and planet formation.<ref name="DirtyStars">{{cite web|last1=American Museum of Natural History|title=Dirty Stars Make Good Solar System Hosts|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2009/10/091006122336.htm|website=ScienceDaily|accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref>
A high average solid to gas ratio may be reached due to the loss of gas or by the concentration of solids.<ref name="Johansen_Jacquet_2015" /> Gas may be selectively lost due to [[photoevaporation]] late in the gas disk epoch,<ref name="Gorti_etal_2015">{{cite journal|last1=Gorti|first1=U.|last2=Hollenbach|first2=D.|last3=Dullemond|first3=C. P.|title=The Impact of Dust Evolution and Photoevaporation on Disk Dispersal|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2015|volume=804|issue=1|page=29|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/804/1/29|arxiv=1502.07369|bibcode=2015ApJ...804...29G}}</ref> causing solids to be concentrated in a ring at the edge of a cavity that forms in the gas disk,<ref name="Alexander_Armitage_2007">{{cite journal|last1=Alexander|first1=R. D.|last2=Armitage|first2=P. J.|title=Dust dynamics during protoplanetary disc clearing|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|date=2007|volume=375|issue=2|pages=500–512|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2006.11341.x|arxiv=astro-ph/0611821|url=http://mnras.oxfordjournals.org/content/375/2/500.full.pdf|bibcode=2007MNRAS.375..500A}}</ref> though the mass of planetesimals that forms may be too small to produce planets.<ref name="Ercolano_etal_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Ercolano|first1=Barbara|last2=Jennings|first2=Jeff|last3=Rosotti|first3=Giovanni|last4=Birnstiel|first4=Tilman|title=X-ray photoevaporation's limited success in the formation of planetesimals by the streaming instability|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|date=2017|volume=472|issue=4|pages=4117–4125|doi=10.1093/mnras/stx2294|arxiv=1709.00361|url=https://academic.oup.com/mnras/article-abstract/472/4/4117/4107123/|bibcode=2017MNRAS.472.4117E}}</ref> The solid to gas ratio can also increase in the outer disk due to photoevaporation, but in the giant planet region the resulting planetesimal formation may be too late to produce giant planets.<ref name="Carrera_etal_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Carrera|first1=Daniel|last2=Gorti|first2=Uma|last3=Johansen|first3=Anders|last4=Davies|first4=Melvyn B.|title=Planetesimal formation by the streaming instability in a photoevaporating disk|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2017|volume=839|issue=1|page=16|doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aa6932|arxiv=1703.07895|bibcode = 2017ApJ...839...16C }}</ref> If the magnetic field of the disc is aligned with its angular momentum the Hall effect increases viscosity which can result in a faster depletion of the inner gas disk.<ref name="Simon_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Simon|first1=Jacob B.|title=The Influence of Magnetic Field Geometry on the Formation of Close-in Exoplanets|journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters|date=2016|volume=827|issue=2|page=L37|doi=10.3847/2041-8205/827/2/L37|arxiv=1608.00573|bibcode = 2016ApJ...827L..37S }}</ref><ref name="Hammer_2016a">{{cite web|last1=Hammer|first1=Michael|title=Why is Mercury so far from the Sun?|url=https://astrobites.org/2016/08/12/why-is-mercury-so-far-from-the-sun/|website=astrobites|accessdate=17 November 2016|date=2016-08-12}}</ref> A pile up of solids in the inner disk can occur due to slower rates of radial drift as Stoke's numbers decline with increasing gas densities.<ref name="Youdin_Chiang_2004">{{cite journal|last1=Youdin|first1=Andrew N.|last2=Chiang|first2=Eugene I.|title=Particle Pileups and Planetesimal Formation|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2004|volume=601|issue=2|pages=1109–1119|doi=10.1086/379368|arxiv=astro-ph/0309247|bibcode=2004ApJ...601.1109Y}}</ref> This radial pile up is reinforced as the velocity of the gas increases with the surface density of solids and could result in the formation of bands of planetesimals extending from sublimation lines to a sharp outer edges where solid to gas ratios first reach critical values.<ref name="Drazkowska_etal_2016" /><ref name="Hammer_2016b">{{cite web|last1=Hammer|first1=Michael|title=Why is Mars so small?|url=https://astrobites.org/2016/09/19/why-is-mars-so-small/|website=astrobites|accessdate=20 June 2017|date=2016-09-19}}</ref><ref name="Armitage_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Armitage|first1=Phillip J.|last2=Eisner|first2=Josh A.|last3=Simon|first3=Jacob B.|title=Prompt Planetesimal Formation beyond the Snow Line|journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters|date=2016|volume=828|issue=1|page=L2|doi=10.3847/2041-8205/828/1/L2|arxiv=1608.03592|bibcode = 2016ApJ...828L...2A }}</ref> For some ranges of particle size and gas viscosity outward flow of the gas may occur, reducing its density and further increasing the solid to gas ratio.<ref name="Kanagawa_etal_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Kanagawa|first1=Kazuhiro D.|last2=Ueda|first2=Takahiro|last3=Muto|first3=Takayuki|last4=Okuzumi|first4=Satoshi|title=Effect of dust radial drift on viscous evolution of gaseous disk|arxiv=1706.08975|date=2017|doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aa7ca1|volume=844|issue=2|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|page=142|bibcode = 2017ApJ...844..142K }}</ref> The radial pile ups may be limited due to a reduction in the gas density as the disk evolves however,<ref name="Hughes_Armitage_2012">{{cite journal|last1=Hughes|first1=Anna L. H.|last2=Armitage|first2=Philip J.|title=Global variation of the dust-to-gas ratio in evolving protoplanetary discs|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society |date=2012|volume=423|issue=1|pages=389–405|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2012.20892.x|arxiv=1203.2940|url=http://mnras.oxfordjournals.org/content/423/1/389|bibcode=2012MNRAS.423..389H}}</ref> and shorter growth timescales of solids closer to the star could instead result in the loss of solids from the inside out.<ref name="Krijt_etal_2016" /> Radial pile-ups also occur at locations where rapidly drifting large solids fragment into smaller slower drifting solids, for example, inside the [[Frost line (astrophysics)|ice line]] where silicate grains are released as icy bodies [[sublimation (phase transition)|sublimate]].<ref name="Saito_Sirono_2011">{{cite journal|last1=Saito|first1=Etsuko|last2=Sirono|first2=Sin-iti|title=Planetesimal Formation by Sublimation|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2011|volume=728|issue=1|page=20|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/728/1/20|bibcode=2011ApJ...728...20S}}</ref> This pile up can also increase the local velocity of the gas, extending the pile up to outside the ice line where it is enhanced by the outward diffusion and recondensation of water vapor.<ref name="Drazkowska_Alibert_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Drazkowska|first1=Joanna|last2=Alibert|first2=Yann|title=Planetesimal formation starts at the snow line|date=2017|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|volume=608|page=A92|arxiv=1710.00009|url=https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2017/12/aa31491-17/aa31491-17.html|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201731491}}</ref> The pile-up could be muted, however, if the icy bodies are highly porous, which slows their radial drift.<ref name="Estada_Cuzzi_2016">{{cite web|last1=Estrada|first1=P. R.|last2=Cuzzi|first2=J. N.|title=Fractal Growth and Radial Migration of Solids: The Role of Porosity and Compaction in an Evolving Nebula|url=http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/2854.pdf|publisher=47th Lunar and Planetary Science Conference}}</ref> Icy solids can be concentrated outside the ice line due to the outward diffusion and recondensation of water vapor.<ref name="Schoonenberg_Ormel_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Schoonenberg|first1=Djoreke|last2=Ormel|first2=Chris W.|title=Planetesimal formation near the snowline: in or out?|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2017|volume=602|page=A21|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201630013|arxiv=1702.02151|bibcode=2017A&A...602A..21S}}</ref><ref name="Hammer_2017b">{{cite web|last1=Hammer|first1=Michael|title=Watermelon Dust is the Best Dust: Forming Planetesimals Near the Snow Line|url=https://astrobites.org/2017/06/16/watermelon-dust-is-the-best-dust-forming-planetesimals-near-the-snow-line/|website=astrobites|accessdate=20 June 2017|date=2017-06-16}}</ref> Solids are also concentrated in radial pressure bumps, where the pressure reaches a local maximum. At these locations radial drift converges from both closer and farther from the star.<ref name="Birnstiel_etal_2016" /> Radial pressure bumps are present at the inner edge of the dead zone,<ref name="Kretke_etal_2009">{{cite journal|last1=Kretke|first1=K. A.|last2=Lin|first2=D. N. C.|last3=Garaud|first3=P.|last4=Turner|first4=N. J.|title=Assembling the Building Blocks of Giant Planets Around Intermediate-Mass Stars|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2009|volume=690|issue=1|pages=407–415|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/690/1/407|arxiv=0806.1521|bibcode=2009ApJ...690..407K}}</ref> and can form due to the [[magnetorotational instability]].<ref name="Dittrich_etal_2013">{{cite journal|last1=Dittrich|first1=K.|last2=Klahr|first2=H.|last3=Johansen|first3=A.|title=Gravoturbulent Planetesimal Formation: The Positive Effect of Long-lived Zonal Flows|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2013|volume=763|issue=2|page=117|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/763/2/117|arxiv=1211.2095|bibcode=2013ApJ...763..117D}}</ref> Pressure bumps may also be produced due to the back-reaction of dust on the gas creating self-induced dust traps.<ref name="Gonzalez_etal_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Gonzalez|first1=J.-F.|last2=Laibe|first2=G.|last3=Maddison|first3=S. T.|title=Self-induced dust traps: overcoming planet formation barriers|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|date=2017|volume=467|issue=2|pages=1984–1996|doi=10.1093/mnras/stx016|arxiv=1701.01115|url=https://academic.oup.com/mnras/article-abstract/467/2/1984/2869861/|bibcode=2017MNRAS.467.1984G}}</ref> The ice line has also been proposed as the site of a pressure bump,<ref name="Kretke_Lin_2007">{{cite journal|last1=Kretke|first1=Katherine A.|last2=Lin|first2=D. N. C.|title=Grain Retention and Formation of Planetesimals near the Snow Line in MRI-driven Turbulent Protoplanetary Disks|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2007|volume=664|issue=1|pages=L55–L58|doi=10.1086/520718|arxiv=0706.1272|bibcode=2007ApJ...664L..55K}}</ref> however, this requires a steep [[viscosity]] transition.<ref name="Bitsch_etal_2014">{{cite journal|last1=Bitsch|first1=Bertram|last2=Morbidelli|first2=Alessandro|last3=Lega|first3=Elena|last4=Kretke|first4=Katherine|last5=Crida|first5=Aurélien|title=Stellar irradiated discs and implications on migration of embedded planets. III. Viscosity transitions|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2014|volume=570|page=A75|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201424015|arxiv=1408.1016|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2014/10/aa24015-14/aa24015-14.html|bibcode=2014A&A...570A..75B}}</ref> If the back-reaction from the concentration of solids flattens the pressure gradient,<ref name="Kato_etal_2012">{{cite journal|last1=Kato|first1=M. T.|last2=Fujimoto|first2=M.|last3=Ida|first3=S.|title=Planetesimal Formation at the Boundary between Steady Super/Sub-Keplerian Flow Created by Inhomogeneous Growth of Magnetorotational Instability|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2012|volume=747|issue=1|page=11|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/747/1/11|arxiv=1112.5264|bibcode=2012ApJ...747...11K}}</ref> the planetesimals formed at a pressure bump may be smaller than predicted at other locations.<ref name="Taki_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Taki|first1=Tetsuo|last2=Fujimoto|first2=Masaki|last3=Ida|first3=Shigeru|title=Dust and gas density evolution at a radial pressure bump in protoplanetary disks|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2016|volume=591|page=A86|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201527732|arxiv=1605.02744|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2016/07/aa27732-15/aa27732-15.html|bibcode=2016A&A...591A..86T}}</ref> If the pressure gradient is maintained streaming instabilities may form at the location of a pressure bump even in viscous disks with significant turbulence.<ref name="Auffinger_Laibe_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Auffinger|first1=Jérémy|last2=Laibe|first2=Guillaume|title=Linear growth of streaming instability in pressure bumps|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|volume=473|pages=796–805|date=2017|arxiv=1709.08660|doi=10.1093/mnras/stx2395}}</ref> Local pressure bumps also form in the spiral arms of a massive self-gravitating disk<ref name="Rice_etal_2004">{{cite journal|last1=Rice|first1=W. K. M.|last2=Lodato|first2=G.|last3=Pringle|first3=J. E.|last4=Armitage|first4=P. J.|last5=Bonnell|first5=I. A.|title=Accelerated planetesimal growth in self-gravitating protoplanetary discs|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|date=2004|volume=355|issue=2|pages=543–552|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2004.08339.x|arxiv=astro-ph/0408390|url=http://mnras.oxfordjournals.org/content/355/2/543|bibcode=2004MNRAS.355..543R}}</ref> and in anti-cyclonic [[vortices]].<ref name="Raettig_etal_2015">{{cite journal|last1=Raettig|first1=Natalie|last2=Klahr|first2=Hubert|last3=Lyra|first3=Wladimir|title=Particle Trapping and Streaming Instability in Vortices in Protoplanetary Disks|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2015|volume=804|issue=1|page=35|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/804/1/35|arxiv=1501.05364|bibcode=2015ApJ...804...35R|hdl=10211.3/173113}}</ref> The break-up of vortices could also leave a ring of solids from which a streaming instability may form.<ref name="Surville_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Surville|first1=Clément|last2=Mayer|first2=Lucio|last3=Lin|first3=Douglas N. C.|title=Dust Capture and Long-lived Density Enhancements Triggered by Vortices in 2D Protoplanetary Disks|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2016|volume=831|issue=1|page=82|doi=10.3847/0004-637X/831/1/82|arxiv=1601.05945|bibcode = 2016ApJ...831...82S }}</ref><ref name="Surville_Mayer_2018">{{cite arXiv|last1=Surville|first1=Clément|last2=Mayer|first2=Lucio|title=Dust-vortex instability in the regime of well-coupled grains|date=2018|eprint=1801.07509|class=astro-ph.EP}}</ref> Solids may also be concentrated locally if disk winds lower the surface density of the inner disc, slowing or reversing their inward drift,<ref name="Suzuki_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Suzuki|first1=Takeru K.|last2=Ogihara|first2=Masahiro|last3=Morbidelli|first3=Alessandro|last4=Crida|first4=Aurélien|last5=Guillot|first5=Tristan|title=Evolution of Protoplanetary Discs with Magnetically Driven Disc Winds|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2016|volume=596|page=A74|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201628955 |arxiv=1609.00437|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2016/12/aa28955-16/aa28955-16.html|bibcode=2016A&A...596A..74S}}</ref> or due to thermal diffusion.<ref name="Hubbard_2015">{{cite journal|last1=Hubbard|first1=Alexander|title=Turbulent thermal diffusion: a way to concentrate dust in protoplanetary discs|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|date=2015|volume=456|issue=3|pages=3079–3089|doi=10.1093/mnras/stv2895|arxiv=1512.02538|url=https://academic.oup.com/mnras/article-abstract/456/3/3079/1105190/Turbulent-thermal-diffusion-a-way-to-concentrate?redirectedFrom=fulltext|bibcode = 2016MNRAS.456.3079H }}</ref>
Streaming instabilities are more likely to form in regions of the disk where: the growth of solids is favored, the pressure gradient is small, and turbulence is low.<ref name="Bai_Stone_2010a">{{cite journal|last1=Bai|first1=Xue-Ning|last2=Stone|first2=James M.|title=Dynamics of Solids in the Midplane of Protoplanetary Disks: Implications for Planetesimal Formation|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2010|volume=722|issue=2|pages=1437–1459|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/722/2/1437|arxiv=1005.4982|bibcode=2010ApJ...722.1437B}}</ref><ref name="Bai_Stone_2010b">{{cite journal|last1=Bai|first1=Xue-Ning|last2=Stone|first2=James M.|title=The Effect of the Radial Pressure Gradient in Protoplanetary Disks on Planetesimal Formation|journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters|date=2010|volume=722|issue=2|pages=L220–L223|doi=10.1088/2041-8205/722/2/L220|arxiv=1005.4981|bibcode = 2010ApJ...722L.220B }}</ref> Inside the ice-line the bouncing barrier may prevent the growth of silicates large enough to take part in streaming instabilities.<ref name=Drazkowska_Dullemond_2014>{{cite journal |last1=Drążkowska |first1=J. |last2=Dullemond |first2=C. P. |date=2014 |title=Can dust coagulation trigger streaming instability? |url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2014/12/aa24809-14.pdf |journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics |volume=572 |page=A78 |arxiv=1410.3832 |bibcode=2014A&A...572A..78D |doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201424809}}</ref> Beyond the ice line hydrogen bonding allows particles of water ice to stick at higher collision velocities,<ref name="Birnstiel_etal_2016" /> possibly enabling the growth of large highly porous icy bodies to Stokes numbers approaching 1 before their growth is slowed by erosion.<ref name="Krijt_etal_2015" /> The condensation of vapor diffusing outward from sublimating icy bodies may also drive the growth of compact dm-size icy bodies outside the ice line.<ref name="Ros_Johansen_2013">{{cite journal|last1=Ros|first1=K.|last2=Johansen|first2=A.|title=Ice condensation as a planet formation mechanism|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2013|volume=552|page=A137|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201220536|arxiv=1302.3755|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2013/04/aa20536-12/aa20536-12.html|bibcode=2013A&A...552A.137R}}</ref> A similar growth of bodies due to recondensation of water could occur over a broader region following an FU Orionis event.<ref name="Hubbard_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Hubbard|first1=Alexander|title=FU Orionis outbursts, preferential recondensation of water ice, and the formation of giant planets|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|date=2017|volume=465|issue=2|pages=1910–1914|doi=10.1093/mnras/stw2882|arxiv=1611.01538|url=https://academic.oup.com/mnras/article-abstract/465/2/1910/2447828/FU-Orionis-outbursts-preferential-recondensation?redirectedFrom=fulltext|bibcode = 2017MNRAS.465.1910H }}</ref> At greater distances the growth of solids could again be limited if they are coated with a layer of CO<sub>2</sub> or other ices that reduce the collision velocities where sticking occurs.<ref name="Musiolik_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Musiolik|first1=Grzegorz|last2=Teiser|first2=Jens|last3=Jankowski|first3=Tim|last4=Wurm|first4=Gerhard|title=Collisions of CO2 Ice Grains in Planet Formation|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2016|volume=818|issue=1|page=16|doi=10.3847/0004-637X/818/1/16|arxiv=1601.04854|bibcode = 2016ApJ...818...16M }}</ref> A small pressure gradient reduces the rate of radial drift, limiting the turbulence generated by streaming instabilities. A smaller average solid to gas ratio is then necessary to suppress turbulence at the mid-plane. The diminished turbulence also enables the growth of larger solids by lowering impact velocities.<ref name="Drazkowska_Dullemond_2014" /> [[hydrodynamics|Hydrodynamic]] models indicate that the smallest pressure gradients occur near the ice-line and in the inner parts of the disk. The pressure gradient also decreases late in the disk's evolution as the accretion rate and the temperature decline.<ref name="Bitsch_etal_2015">{{cite journal|last1=Bitsch|first1=Bertram|last2=Johansen|first2=Anders|last3=Lambrechts|first3=Michiel|last4=Morbidelli|first4=Alessandro|title=The structure of protoplanetary discs around evolving young stars|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2015|volume=575|page=A28|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201424964|arxiv=1411.3255|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2015/03/aa24964-14/aa24964-14.html|bibcode=2015A&A...575A..28B}}</ref> A major source of turbulence in the protoplanetary disk is the magnetorotational instability. The impacts of turbulence generated by this instability could limit streaming instabilities to the dead zone, estimated to form near the mid-plane at 1-20 AU, where the [[ionization]] rate is too low to sustain the magnetorotational instability.<ref name="Johansen_Jacquet_2015" />
In the inner Solar System the formation of streaming instabilities requires a larger enhancement of the solid to gas ratio than beyond the ice line. The growth of silicate particles is limited by the bouncing barrier to ~1 mm, roughly the size of the chondrules found in meteorites. In the inner Solar System particles this small have Stokes numbers of ~0.001. At these Stokes numbers a vertically integrated solid to gas ratio greater than 0.04, roughly four times that of the overall gas disk, is required to form streaming instabilities.<ref name="Yang_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Yang|first1=Chao-Chin|last2=Johansen|first2=Anders|last3=Carrera|first3=Daniel|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|volume=606|page=A80|title=Concentrating small particles in protoplanetary disks through the streaming instability|arxiv=1611.07014|url=https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2017/10/aa30106-16/aa30106-16.html|date=2016|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201630106|bibcode=2017A&A...606A..80Y}}</ref> The required concentration may be reduced by half if the particles are able to grow to roughly cm-size.<ref name="Yang_etal_2016" /> This growth, possibly aided by dusty rims that absorb impacts,<ref name="Ormel_etal_2008">{{cite journal|last1=Ormel|first1=C. W.|last2=Cuzzi|first2=J. N.|last3=Tielens|first3=A. G. G. M.|title=Co-Accretion of Chondrules and Dust in the Solar Nebula|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2008|volume=679|issue=2|pages=1588–1610|doi=10.1086/587836|arxiv=0802.4048|bibcode=2008ApJ...679.1588O}}</ref> may occur over a period of 10^5 years if a fraction of collisions result in sticking due to a broad distribution of collision velocities.<ref name=Carrera_2015>{{cite journal |last1=Carrera |first1=D. |last2=Johansen |first2=A. |last3=Davies |first3=M. B. |date=2015 |title=How to form planetesimals from mm-sized chondrules and chondrule aggregates |journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics |volume=579 |page=A43 |arxiv=1501.05314 |bibcode=2015A&A...579A..43C |doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201425120}}</ref> Or, if turbulence and the collision velocities are reduced inside initial weak clumps, a runaway process may occur in which clumping aids the growth of solids and their growth strengthens clumping.<ref name="Carrera_2015" /> A radial pile-up of solids may also lead to conditions that support streaming instabilities in a narrow annulus at roughly 1 AU. This would requires a shallow initial disk profile and that the growth of solids be limited by fragmentation instead of bouncing allowing cm-sized solids to form, however.<ref name="Drazkowska_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Drążkowska|first1=J.|last2=Alibert|first2=Y.|last3=Moore|first3=B.|title=Close-in planetesimal formation by pile-up of drifting pebbles|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2016|volume=594|page=A105|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201628983|arxiv=1607.05734|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2016/10/aa28983-16/aa28983-16.html|bibcode=2016A&A...594A.105D}}</ref> The growth of particles may be further limited at high temperatures, possibly leading to an inner boundary of planetesimal formation where temperatures reaches 1000K.<ref name="Demirci_etal_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Demirci|first1=Tunahan|last2=Teiser|first2=Jens|last3=Steinpilz|first3=Tobias|last4=Landers|first4=Joachim|last5=Salamon|first5=Soma|last6=Wende|first6=Heiko|last7=Wurm|first7=Gerhard|title=Is There a Temperature Limit in Planet Formation at 1000 K?|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=846|pages=48|date=2017|arxiv=1710.00606|doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aa816c}}</ref>
==Alternatives== Instead of actively driving their own concentration, as in streaming instabilities, solids may be passively concentrated to sufficient densities for planetesimals to form via gravitational instabilities.<ref name="Protostars_and Planets_2014" /> In an early proposal dust settled at the mid-plane until sufficient densities were reached for the disk to gravitationally fragment and collapse into planetesimals.<ref name="Goldreich_Ward_1973">{{cite journal|last1=Goldreich|first1=Peter|last2=Ward|first2=William R.|title=The Formation of Planetesimals|journal=Astrophysical Journal|date=1973|volume=183|pages=1051–1062|doi=10.1086/152291|bibcode=1973ApJ...183.1051G}}</ref> The difference in orbital velocities of the dust and gas, however, produces turbulence which inhibits settling preventing sufficient densities from being reached. If the average dust to gas ratio is increased by an order of magnitude at a pressure bump or by the slower drift of small particles derived from fragmenting larger bodies,<ref name="Sirono_2011b">{{cite journal|last1=Sirono|first1=Sin-iti|title=Planetesimal Formation Induced by Sintering|journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters|date=2011|volume=733|issue=2|page=L41|doi=10.1088/2041-8205/733/2/L41|bibcode = 2011ApJ...733L..41S }}</ref><ref name="Ida_Guillot_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Ida|first1=S.|last2=Guillot|first2=T.|title=Formation of dust-rich planetesimals from sublimated pebbles inside of the snow line|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2016|volume=596|page=L3|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201629680|arxiv=1610.09643|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2016/12/aa29680-16/aa29680-16.html|bibcode=2016A&A...596L...3I}}</ref> this turbulence may be suppressed allowing the formation of planetesimals.<ref name="Youdin_Shu_2002">{{cite journal|last1=Youdin|first1=Andrew N.|last2=Shu|first2=Frank H.|title=Planetesimal Formation by Gravitational Instability|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2002|volume=580|issue=1|pages=494–505|doi=10.1086/343109|bibcode=2002ApJ...580..494Y|arxiv = astro-ph/0207536 }}</ref>
The cold classical Kuiper belt objects may have formed in a low mass disk dominated by cm-sized or smaller objects. In this model the gas disk epoch ends with km-sized objects, possibly formed via gravitational instability, embedded in a disk of small objects. The disk remains dynamically cool due to inelastic collisions among the cm-sized objects. The slow encounter velocities result in efficient growth with a sizable fraction of the mass ending in the large objects.<ref name="Shannon_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Shannon|first1=Andrew|last2=Wu|first2=Yanquin|last3=Lithwick|first3=Yoram|title=Forming the Cold Classical Kuiper Belt in a Light Disk|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2016|volume=818|issue=2|page=175|doi=10.3847/0004-637X/818/2/175|arxiv=1510.01323|bibcode = 2016ApJ...818..175S }}</ref> The dynamical friction from the small bodies would also aid in the formation of binaries.<ref name="Fraser_etal_2017">{{cite journal|last1=Fraser|first1=Wesley C.|last2=and 21 others|title=All planetesimals born near the Kuiper belt formed as binaries|journal=Nature Astronomy|date=2017|volume=1|issue=4|page=0088|doi=10.1038/s41550-017-0088|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41550-017-0088|arxiv = 1705.00683 |bibcode = 2017NatAs...1E..88F }}</ref><ref name="Goldreich_etal_2002">{{cite journal|last1=Goldreich|first1=Peter|last2=Lithwick|first2=Yoram|last3=Sari|first3=Re'em|title=Formation of Kuiper-belt binaries by dynamical friction and three-body encounters|journal=Nature|date=2002|volume=420|issue=6916|pages=643–+646|doi=10.1038/nature01227|pmid=12478286|arxiv=astro-ph/0208490|url=https://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v420/n6916/full/nature01227.html|bibcode = 2002Natur.420..643G }}</ref>
Planetesimals may also be formed from the concentration of chondrules between eddies in a turbulent disk. In this model the particles are split unequally when large eddies fragment increasing the concentrations of some clumps. As this process cascades to smaller eddies a fraction of these clumps may reach densities sufficient to be gravitationally bound and slowly collapse into planetesimals.<ref name="Cuzzi_Hogan_2012">{{cite web|last1=Cuzzi, J. N.;|first1=J. N.|last2=Hogan, R. C.|first2=R. C.|title=Primary Accretion by Turbulent Concentration: The Rate of Planetesimal Formation and the Role of Vortex Tubes|url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2012/pdf/2536.pdf|publisher=43rd Lunar and Planetary Science Conference}}</ref> Recent research, however, indicates that larger objects such as conglomerates of chondrules may be necessary and that the concentrations produced from chondrules may instead act as the seeds of streaming instabilities.<ref name="Cuzzi_etal_2016a">{{cite web|last1=Cuzzi|first1=J. N.|last2=Hartlep|first2=T.|last3=Estrada|first3=P. R.|title=Planetesimal Initial Mass Functions and Creation Rates Under Turbulent Concentration Using Scale-Dependent Cascades|url=http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/2661.pdf|publisher=47th Lunar and Planetary Science Conference}}</ref>
Icy particles are more likely to stick and to resist compression in collisions which may allow the growth of large porous bodies. If the growth of these bodies is [[fractal]], with their porosity increasing as larger porous bodies collide, their radial drift timescales become long, allowing them to grow until they are compressed by gas drag and self-gravity forming small planetesimimals.<ref name="Okuzumi_etal_2012">{{cite journal|last1=Okuzumi|first1=Satoshi|last2=Tanaka|first2=Hidekazu|last3=Kobayashi|first3=Hiroshi|last4=Wada|first4=Koji|title=Rapid Coagulation of Porous Dust Aggregates outside the Snow Line: A Pathway to Successful Icy Planetesimal Formation|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2012|volume=752|issue=2|page=106|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/752/2/106|arxiv=1204.5035|bibcode = 2012ApJ...752..106O }}</ref><ref name="Kataoka_etal_2013">{{cite journal|last1=Kataoka|first1=Akimasa|last2=Tanaka|first2=Hidekazu|last3=Okuzumi|first3=Satoshi|last4=Wada|first4=Koji|title=Fluffy dust forms icy planetesimals by static compression|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2013|volume=557|page=L4|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201322151|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2013/09/aa22151-13/aa22151-13.html|bibcode=2013A&A...557L...4K|arxiv = 1307.7984 }}</ref> Alternatively, if the local solid density of the disk is sufficient, they may settle into a thin disk that fragments due to a gravitational instability, forming planetesimals the size of large asteroids, once they grow large enough to become decoupled from the gas.<ref name="Michikoshi_Kokubo_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Michikoshi|first1=Shugo|last2=Kokubo|first2=Eiichiro|title=Planetesimal Formation by Gravitational Instability of a Porous Dust Disk|journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters|date=2016|volume=825|issue=2|page=L28|doi=10.3847/2041-8205/825/2/L28|arxiv=1606.06824|bibcode = 2016ApJ...825L..28M }}</ref> A similar fractal growth of porous silicates may also be possible if they are made up of nanometer-sized grains formed from the evaporation and recondensation of dust.<ref name="Arakawa_Nakamoto_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Arakawa|first1=Sota|last2=Nakamoto|first2=Taishi|title=Rocky Planetesimal Formation via Fluffy Aggregates of Nanograins|journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters|date=2016|volume=832|issue=2|page=L19|doi=10.3847/2041-8205/832/2/L19|arxiv=1611.03859|bibcode = 2016ApJ...832L..19A }}</ref> However, the fractal growth of highly porous solids may be limited by the infilling of their cores with small particles generated in collisions due to turbulence;<ref name="Dominik_etal_2016">{{cite arXiv|last1=Dominik|first1=Carsten|last2=Paszun|first2=Dominik|last3=Borel|first3=Herman|title=The structure of dust aggregates in hierarchical coagulation|eprint=1611.00167|date=2016|class=astro-ph.EP}}</ref> by erosion as the impact velocity due to the relative rates of radial drift of large and small bodies increases;<ref name="Krijt_etal_2015">{{cite journal|last1=Krijt|first1=S.|last2=Ormel|first2=C. W.|last3=Dominik|first3=C.|last4=Tielens|first4=A. G. G. M.|title=Erosion and the limits to planetesimal growth|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2015|volume=574|page=A83|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201425222|arxiv=1412.3593|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2015/02/aa25222-14/aa25222-14.html|bibcode = 2015A&A...574A..83K }}</ref> and by [[sintering]] as they approach ice lines, reducing their ability to absorb collisions, resulting in bouncing or fragmentation during collisions.<ref name="Sirono_2011a">{{cite journal|last1=Sirono|first1=Sin-iti|title=The Sintering Region of Icy Dust Aggregates in a Protoplanetary Nebula|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2011|volume=735|issue=2|page=131|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/735/2/131|bibcode = 2011ApJ...735..131S }}</ref>
Collisions at velocities that would result in the fragmentation of equal sized particles can instead result in growth via mass transfer from the small to the larger particle. This process requires an initial population of 'lucky' particles that have grown larger than the majority of particles.<ref name="Windmark_etal_2012">{{cite journal|last1=Windmark|first1=F.|last2=Birnstiel|first2=T.|last3=Güttler|first3=C.|last4=Blum|first4=J.|last5=Dullemond|first5=C. P.|last6=Henning|first6=Th.|title=Planetesimal formation by sweep-up: how the bouncing barrier can be beneficial to growth|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2012|volume=540|page=A73|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201118475|arxiv=1201.4282|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2012/04/aa18475-11/aa18475-11.html|bibcode = 2012A&A...540A..73W }}</ref> These particles may form if collision velocities have a wide distribution, with a small fraction occurring at velocities that allow objects beyond the bouncing barrier to stick. However, the growth via mass transfer is slow relative to radial drift timescales, although it may occur locally if radial drift is halted locally at a pressure bump allowing the formation of planetesimals in 10^5 yrs.<ref name="Drazkoska_etal_2013">{{cite journal|last1=Drążkowska|first1=J.|last2=Windmark|first2=F.|last3=Dullemond|first3=C. P.|title=Planetesimal formation via sweep-up growth at the inner edge of dead zones|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|date=2013|volume=556|page=A37|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201321566|arxiv=1306.3412|url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2013/08/aa21566-13/aa21566-13.html|bibcode=2013A&A...556A..37D}}</ref>
Planetesimal accretion could reproduce the size distribution of the asteroids if it began with 100 meter planetesimals. In this model collisional dampening and gas drag dynamically cool the disk and the bend in the size distribution is caused by a transition between growth regimes.<ref name="Weidenschilling_2011">{{cite journal|last1=Weidenschilling, S. J.|first1=S. J.|title=Initial sizes of planetesimals and accretion of the asteroids|journal=Icarus|date=2011|volume=214|issue=2|pages=671–684|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2011.05.024|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103511001977|bibcode=2011Icar..214..671W}}</ref><ref name="Weidenschlling_2010">{{cite web|last1=Weidenschilling, S. J.|first1=S. J.|title=Were Asteroids Born Big? An Alternative Scenario|url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2010/pdf/1453.pdf|publisher=41st Lunar and Planetary Science Conference held March 1–5, 2010}}</ref> This however require a low level of turbulence in the gas and some mechanism for the formation of 100 meter planetesimals.<ref name="Johansen_Jacquet_2015" /> Size dependent clearing of planetesimals due to secular resonance sweeping could also remove small bodies creating a break in the size distribution of asteroids. Secular resonances sweeping inward through the asteroid belt as the gas disk dissipated would excite the eccentricities of the planetesimals. As their eccentricities were damped due to gas drag and tidal interaction with the disk the largest and smallest objects would be lost as their semi-major axes shrank leaving behind the intermediate sized planetesimals.<ref name="Zheng_etal_2016">{{cite journal|last1=Zheng|first1=Xiaochen|last2=Lin|first2=Douglas N. C.|last3=Kouwenhoven|first3=M. B. N.|title=Planetesimal clearing and size-dependent asteroid retention by secular resonance sweeping during the depletion of the solar nebula|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|date=2016|volume=836|issue=2|page=207|doi=10.3847/1538-4357/836/2/207|arxiv=1610.09670|bibcode = 2017ApJ...836..207Z }}</ref>
==External links== * [http://jila.colorado.edu/~jasi1566/3dstreaminginsta.html Numerical Simulation of 3D Streaming Instability]

[[Category:Solar System dynamic theories]]

The '''Transporter Classification Database''' (or '''TCDB''') is an [[International Union of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology]] (IUBMB)-approved classification system for [[membrane transport protein]]s, including [[ion channel]]s.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Saier|first1=Milton H.|last2=Reddy|first2=Vamsee S.|last3=Tamang|first3=Dorjee G.|last4=Västermark|first4=Åke|title=The Transporter Classification Database|journal=Nucleic Acids Research|date=January 2014|volume=42|issue=D1|pages=D251–D258|doi=10.1093/nar/gkt1097|url=http://nar.oxfordjournals.org/content/42/D1/D251|accessdate=1 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Saier|first1=M. H.|last2=Yen|first2=M. R.|last3=Noto|first3=K.|last4=Tamang|first4=D. G.|last5=Elkan|first5=C.|title=The Transporter Classification Database: recent advances|journal=Nucleic Acids Research|date=1 January 2009|volume=37|issue=Database|pages=D274–D278|doi=10.1093/nar/gkn862|url=http://nar.oxfordjournals.org/content/37/suppl_1/D274|accessdate=1 March 2016|pmid=19022853|pmc=2686586}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Saier|first1=M. H.|last2=Tran|first2=C. V.|last3=Barabote|first3=R. D.|title=TCDB: the Transporter Classification Database for membrane transport protein analyses and information|journal=Nucleic Acids Research|date=1 January 2006|volume=34|issue=90001|pages=D181–D186|doi=10.1093/nar/gkj001|url=http://nar.oxfordjournals.org/content/34/suppl_1/D181|accessdate=1 March 2016|pmid=16381841|pmc=1334385}}</ref>

cation:proton antiporter-3|Monovalent Cation:Proton Antiporter-2]] (CPA2) Family *2.A.38 [[Potassium transporter family|K<sup>+</sup> Transporter (Trk)]] Family *2.A.39 [[Nucleobase cation symporter-1|Nucleobase:Cation Symporter-1]] (NCS1) Family *2.A.40 [[Nucleobase cation symporter-2|Nucleobase:Cation Symporter-2]] (NCS2) Family *2.A.41 The Concentrative Nucleoside Transporter (CNT) Family *2.A.42 The Hydroxy/Aromatic Amino Acid Permease (HAAAP) Family *2.A.43 The Lysosomal Cystine Transporter (LCT) Family *2.A.45 [[Arsenite-antimonite transporter|Arsenite-Antimonite Efflux Family]] *2.A.46 The Benzoate:H<sup>+</sup> Symporter (BenE) Family *2.A.47 [[Divalent anion–sodium symporter|Divalent Anion:Na<sup>+</sup> Symporter]] (DASS) Family *2.A.48 The Reduced Folate Carrier (RFC) Family *2.A.49 [[Chloride channel|Chloride Carrier/Channel]] (ClC) Family *2.A.50 The Glycerol Uptake (GUP) Family *2.A.51 The Chromate Ion Transporter (CHR) Family *2.A.52 The Ni<sup>2+</sup>-Co<sup>2+</sup> Transporter (NiCoT) Family *2.A.53 [[Sulfate permease]] (SulP) Family *2.A.54 The Mitochondrial Tricarboxylate Carrier (MTC) Family *2.A.55 [[Natural Resistance-Associated Macrophage Proteins|The Metal Ion (Mn<sup>2+</sup>-iron) Transporter]] (Nramp) Family *2.A.56 The Tripartite ATP-independent Periplasmic Transporter (TRAP-T) Family *2.A.57 The Equilibrative Nucleoside Transporter (ENT) Family *2.A.58 The Phosphate:Na<sup>+</sup> Symporter (PNaS) Family *2.A.59 The Arsenical Resistance-3 (ACR3) Family *2.A.60 [[Organo anion transporter family|Organo Anion Transporter]] (OAT) Family *2.A.61 The C4-dicarboxylate Uptake C (DcuC) Family *2.A.62 The NhaD Na<sup>+</sup>:H<sup>+</sup> Antiporter (NhaD) Family *2.A.63 The Monovalent Cation (K<sup>+</sup> or Na<sup>+</sup>):Proton Antiporter-3 (CPA3) Family *2.A.64 [[Twin-arginine translocation pathway|Twin Arginine Targeting (Tat) Family]] *2.A.65 The Bilirubin Transporter (BRT) Family *2.A.66 The Multidrug/Oligosaccharidyl-lipid/Polysaccharide (MOP) Flippase Superfamily *2.A.67 The Oligopeptide Transporter (OPT) Family *2.A.68 The p-Aminobenzoyl-glutamate Transporter (AbgT) Family *2.A.69 The Auxin Efflux Carrier (AEC) Family *2.A.70 The Malonate:Na<sup>+</sup> Symporter (MSS) Family *2.A.71 The Folate-Biopterin Transporter (FBT) Family *2.A.72 The K<sup>+</sup> Uptake Permease (KUP) Family *2.A.73 The Short Chain Fatty Acid Uptake (AtoE) Family *2.A.74 The 4 TMS Multidrug Endosomal Transporter (MET) Family *2.A.75 The L-Lysine Exporter (LysE) Family *2.A.76 The Resistance to Homoserine/Threonine (RhtB) Family *2.A.77 The Cadmium Resistance (CadD) Family *2.A.78 The Branched Chain Amino Acid Exporter (LIV-E) Family *2.A.79 The Threonine/Serine Exporter (ThrE) Family *2.A.80 The Tricarboxylate Transporter (TTT) Family *2.A.81 The Aspartate:Alanine Exchanger (AAEx) Family *2.A.82 The Organic Solute Transporter (OST) Family *2.A.83 The Na<sup>+</sup>-dependent Bicarbonate Transporter (SBT) Family *2.A.84 The Chloroplast Maltose Exporter (MEX) Family *2.A.85 The Aromatic Acid Exporter (ArAE) Family *2.A.86 The Autoinducer-2 Exporter (AI-2E) Family (Formerly the PerM Family, TC #9.B.22) *2.A.87 The Prokaryotic Riboflavin Transporter (P-RFT) Family *2.A.88 Vitamin Uptake Transporter (VUT or ECF) Family *2.A.89 The Vacuolar Iron Transporter (VIT) Family *2.A.90 [[Vitamin A receptor|Vitamin A Receptor/Transporter]] (STRA6) Family *2.A.91 Mitochondrial tRNA Import Complex (M-RIC) (Formerly 9.C.8) *2.A.92 The Choline Transporter-like (CTL) Family *2.A.94 The Phosphate Permease (Pho1) Family *2.A.95 The 6TMS Neutral Amino Acid Transporter (NAAT) Family *2.A.96 The Acetate Uptake Transporter (AceTr) Family *2.A.97 The Mitochondrial Inner Membrane K<sup>+</sup>/H<sup>+</sup> and Ca<sup>2+</sup>/H<sup>+</sup> Exchanger (LetM1) Family *2.A.98 The Putative Sulfate Exporter (PSE) Family *2.A.99 The 6TMS Ni<sup>2+</sup> uptake transporter (HupE-UreJ) Family *2.A.100 The Ferroportin (Fpn) Family *2.A.101 The Malonate Uptake (MatC) Family (Formerly UIT1) *2.A.102 The 4-Toluene Sulfonate Uptake Permease (TSUP) Family *2.A.103 The Bacterial Murein Precursor Exporter (MPE) Family *2.A.104 The L-Alanine Exporter (AlaE) Family *2.A.105 The Mitochondrial Pyruvate Carrier (MPC) Family *2.A.106 The Ca<sup>2+</sup>:H<sup>+</sup> Antiporter-2 (CaCA2) Family *2.A.107 The MntP Mn<sup>2+</sup> Exporter (MntP) Family *2.A.108 The Iron/Lead Transporter (ILT) Family *2.A.109 The Tellurium Ion Resistance (TerC) Family *2.A.110 The Heme Transporter, heme-responsive gene protein (HRG) Family *2.A.111 The Na<sup>+</sup>/H<sup>+</sup> Antiporter-E (NhaE) Family *2.A.112 The KX Blood-group Antigen (KXA) Family *2.A.113 The Nickel/cobalt Transporter (NicO) Family *2.A.114 The Putative Peptide Transporter Carbon Starvation CstA (CstA) Family *2.A.115 The Novobiocin Exporter (NbcE) Family *2.A.116 The Peptidoglycolipid Addressing Protein (GAP) Family *2.A.117 The Chlorhexadine Exporter (CHX) family *2.A.118 The Basic Amino Acid Antiporter (ArcD) Family *2.A.119 The Organo-Arsenical Exporter (ArsP) Family *2.A.120 The Putative Amino Acid Permease (PAAP) Family *2.A.121 The Sulfate Transporter (CysZ) Family *2.A.122 The LrgB/CidB holin-like auxiliary protein (LrgB/CidB) Family *2.A.123 The Sweet; PQ-loop; Saliva; MtN3 (Sweet) Family *2.A.124 The Lysine Exporter (LysO) Family *2.A.125 The Eukaryotic Riboflavin Transporter (E-RFT) Family *2.A.126 The Fatty Acid Exporter (FAX) Family *2.A.127 Enterobacterial Cardiolipin Transporter (CLT) Family
====2.B Nonribosomally synthesized porters==== *2.B.1 The [[Valinomycin]] Carrier Family *2.B.2 The [[Monensin]] Family *2.B.3 The [[Nigericin]] Family *2.B.4 The [[Macrotetrolide]] Antibiotic (MA) Family *2.B.5 The Macrocyclic Polyether (MP) Family *2.B.6 The [[Ionomycin]] Family *2.B.7 The Transmembrane α-helical Peptide Phospholipid Translocation (TMP-PLT) Family *2.B.8 The [[Bafilomycin]] A1 (Bafilomycin) Family *2.B.9 The [[Cell Penetrating Peptide]] (CPP) Functional Family *2.B.10 The Synthetic CPP, [[Transportan]] Family *2.B.11 The [[Calcimycin]] or A23187 Carrier-type Ionophore Family *2.B.12 The [[Salinomycin]] Family *2.B.13 The Tetrapyrrolic Macrocyclic Anion Antiporter (TPMC-AA) Family *2.B.14 The Lasalocid A or X-537A Ionophore (Lasalocid) Family *2.B.15 The Tris-thiourea Tripodal-based Chloride Carrier (TTT-CC) Family *2.B.16 The Halogen-bond-containing Compound Anion Carrier (HCAC) Family *2.B.17 The Isophthalaminde Derivative H<sup>+</sup>:Cl<sup>−</sup> Co-transporter (IDC) Family *2.B.18 The Pyridine-2,6-Dicarboxamine Derivative (PDCA) H+:Cl<sup>−</sup> Co-transporter Family *2.B.19 The Calix(4)pyrrole Derivative (C4P) Family *2.B.20 The Prodigiosin (Prodigiosin) Chloride/Bicarbonate Exchanger Family *2.B.21 The ortho-Phenylenediamine-bis-Urea Derivative Anion Transporter (oPDA-U) Family *2.B.22 The Imidazolium-functionalized Anion Transporter (IAT) Family *2.B.23 The Homotetrameric Transmembrane Zn<sup>2+</sup>/Co<sup>2+</sup>:Proton Synthetic Antiporter, Rocker (Rocker) Family *2.B.24 The 2,6-Bis(benzimidazol-2-yl)pyridine Anion Carrier (BBP-AC) Family *2.B.25 The Peptide-mediated Lipid Flip-Flop (PLFF) Family *2.B.26 The Bis(imidazolyl)-functionalized Bis(Choloyl) Conjugate (BIBCC) Family *2.B.27 The Tris-Urea Anion Transporter Family *2.B.29 The Anionophoric Marine Alkaloid [[Tambjamine]] Family
====2.C Ion-gradient-driven energizers==== *2.C.1 The TonB-ExbB-ExbD/TolA-TolQ-TolR (TonB) Family of Auxiliary Proteins for Energization of Outer Membrane Receptor (OMR)-mediated Active Transport
===3. [[Primary active transport]]ers===
====3.A. P-P-bond hydrolysis-driven transporters==== *3.A.1 [[ABC transporter]]s including BtuCD, molybdate uptake transporter, [[Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator]] and others *3.A.2 The H<sup>+</sup>- or Na<sup>+</sup>-translocating [[F-type ATPase]], [[V-type ATPase]] and A-type ATPase superfamily *3.A.3 [[P-type ATPase|The P-type ATPase]] Superfamily *3.A.4 [[ArsB and ArsAB transporters|The Arsenite-Antimonite efflux]] family *3.A.5 [[SecY protein|General secretory pathway]] (Sec) [[translocon]] (preprotein translocase SecY) *3.A.6 The Type III (Virulence-related) Secretory Pathway (IIISP) Family *3.A.7 The Type IV (Conjugal DNA-Protein Transfer or VirB) Secretory Pathway (IVSP) Family *3.A.8 The Mitochondrial Protein Translocase (MPT) Family *3.A.9 The Chloroplast Envelope Protein Translocase (CEPT or Tic-Toc) Family *3.A.10 [[H+, Na+-translocating pyrophosphatase family|H<sup>+</sup>, Na<sup>+</sup>-translocating Pyrophosphatase]] family *3.A.11 The Bacterial Competence-related DNA Transformation Transporter (DNA-T) Family *3.A.12 The Septal DNA Translocator (S-DNA-T) Family *3.A.13 The Filamentous Phage Exporter (FPhE) Family *3.A.14 The Fimbrilin/Protein Exporter (FPE) Family *3.A.15 The Outer Membrane Protein Secreting Main Terminal Branch (MTB) Family *3.A.16 The Endoplasmic Reticular Retrotranslocon (ER-RT) Family *3.A.17 The Phage T7 Injectisome (T7 Injectisome) Family *3.A.18 The Nuclear mRNA Exporter (mRNA-E) Family *3.A.19 The TMS Recognition/Insertion Complex (TRC) Family *3.A.20 The Peroxisomal Protein Importer (PPI) Family *3.A.21 The C-terminal Tail-Anchored Membrane Protein Biogenesis/ Insertion Complex (TAMP-B) Family *3.A.22 The Transcription-coupled TREX/TAP Nuclear mRNA Export Complex (TREX) Family *3.A.23 The Type VI Symbiosis/Virulence Secretory Pathway (VISP) Family *3.A.24 Type VII or ESX Protein Secretion System (T7SS) Family *3.A.25 The Symbiont-specific ERAD-like Machinery (SELMA) Family *3.A.26 The Plasmodium Translocon of Exported proteins (PTEX) Family
====3.B Decarboxylation-driven transporters==== *3.B.1 The Na<sup>+</sup>-transporting Carboxylic Acid Decarboxylase (NaT-DC) Family
====3.C Methyltransfer-driven transporters==== *3.C.1 The Na<sup>+</sup> Transporting Methyltetrahydromethanopterin:Coenzyme M Methyltransferase (NaT-MMM) Family
====3.D. Oxidoreduction-driven transporters==== They include a number of transmembrane [[cytochrome b]]-like proteins including [[coenzyme Q - cytochrome c reductase]] (cytochrome bc1 ); [[cytochrome b6f complex]]; formate dehydrogenase, respiratory [[nitrate reductase]]; [[succinate - coenzyme Q reductase]] (fumarate reductase); and [[succinate dehydrogenase]]. See [[electron transport chain]].
*3.D.1 [[NADH:ubiquinone reductase (H+-translocating)|The H<sup>+</sup> or Na<sup>+</sup>-translocating NADH Dehydrogenase]] ("complex I") family *3.D.2 The Proton-translocating Transhydrogenase (PTH) Family *3.D.3 [[Cytochrome c nitrite reductase|The Proton-translocating Quinol:Cytochrome c Reductase]]) Superfamily *3.D.4 [[Cytochrome c oxidase|Proton-translocating Cytochrome Oxidase]] (COX) Superfamily *3.D.5 The Na<sup>+</sup>-translocating NADH:Quinone Dehydrogenase (Na-NDH or NQR) Family *3.D.6 The Putative Ion (H<sup>+</sup> or Na<sup>+</sup>)-translocating NADH:Ferredoxin Oxidoreductase (NFO or RNF) Family *3.D.7 The H<sub>2</sub>:Heterodisulfide Oxidoreductase (HHO) Family *3.D.8 The Na<sup>+</sup>- or H<sup>+</sup>-Pumping Formyl Methanofuran Dehydrogenase (FMF-DH) Family *3.D.9 The H<sup>+</sup>-translocating F420H2 Dehydrogenase (F420H2DH) Family *3.D.10 The Prokaryotic Succinate Dehydrogenase (SDH) Family
====3.E. Light absorption-driven transporters==== *[[Bacteriorhodopsin]]-like proteins including [[rhodopsin]] (see also [[opsin]]) *Bacterial [[photosynthetic reaction centre]]s and [[photosystem]]s I and II *[[Light harvesting complex]]es from [[bacteria]] and [[chloroplasts]]
===4. Group translocators===
====4.A Phosphotransfer-driven group translocators==== {{main|PTS-GFL superfamily}}
*4.A.1 [[The PTS glucose-glucoside (Glc) family|The PTS Glucose-Glucoside (Glc) Family]] *4.A.2 The PTS Fructose-Mannitol (Fru) Family *4.A.3 The PTS Lactose-N,N'-Diacetylchitobiose-β-glucoside (Lac) Family *4.A.4 The PTS Glucitol (Gut) Family *4.A.5 The PTS Galactitol (Gat) Family *4.A.6 The PTS Mannose-Fructose-Sorbose (Man) Family *4.A.7 The PTS L-Ascorbate (L-Asc) Family
====4.B Nicotinamide ribonucleoside uptake transporters==== *4.B.1 The Nicotinamide Ribonucleoside (NR) Uptake Permease (PnuC) Family
====4.C Acyl CoA ligase-coupled transporters==== *4.C.1 The Proposed Fatty Acid Transporter (FAT) Family *4.C.2 The Carnitine O-Acyl Transferase (CrAT) Family *4.C.3 The Acyl-CoA Thioesterase (AcoT) Family
====4.D Polysaccharide Synthase/Exporters==== *4.D.1 The Putative Vectorial Glycosyl Polymerization (VGP) Family *4.D.2 The Glycosyl Transferase 2 (GT2) Family *4.D.3 The Glycan Glucosyl Transferase (OpgH) Family
====4.E. Vacuolar Polyphosphate Polymerase-catalyzed Group Translocators==== *4.E.1 The Vacuolar (Acidocalcisome) Polyphosphate Polymerase (V-PPP) Family
===5. Transport electron carriers=== ====5.A Transmembrane 2-electron transfer carriers==== *5.A.1 The Disulfide Bond Oxidoreductase D (DsbD) Family *5.A.2 The Disulfide Bond Oxidoreductase B (DsbB) Family *5.A.3 The Prokaryotic Molybdopterin-containing Oxidoreductase (PMO) Family
====5.B Transmembrane 1-electron transfer carriers==== *5.B.1 The Phagocyte (gp91phox) NADPH Oxidase Family *5.B.2 The Eukaryotic Cytochrome b561 (Cytb561) Family *5.B.3 The Geobacter Nanowire Electron Transfer (G-NET) Family *5.B.4 The Plant Photosystem I Supercomplex (PSI) Family *5.B.5 The Extracellular Metal Oxido-Reductase (EMOR) Family *5.B.6 The Transmembrane Epithelial Antigen Protein-3 Ferric Reductase (STEAP) Family *5.B.7 The YedZ (YedZ) Family *5.B.8 The Trans-Outer Membrane Electron Transfer Porin/Cytochrome Complex (ET-PCC) Family *5.B.9 The Porin-Cytochrome c (Cyc2) Family
===8. Accessory factors involved in transport===
====8.A Auxiliary transport proteins====
====8.B Ribosomally synthesized protein/peptide toxins that target channels and carriers====
====8.C Non-ribosomally synthesized toxins that target channels and carriers====
===9. Incompletely characterized transport systems===
