page.title: WHO Model List of Essential Medicines

revision.comment: Reverted to revision 866985911 by [[Special:Contributions/Doc James|Doc James]] ([[User talk:Doc James|talk]]): ? ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
[[File:V1 40 years Model List of Essential Medicines.001.png|thumb|upright=1.4|alt=World map with the words "40 years of the model list of essential medicines 1977–2017" |2017 marked the 40th anniversary of the WHO Model List of Essential Medicines.]] <!-- Definition --> The '''WHO Model List of Essential Medicines''' ('''EML'''), published by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO), contains the medications considered to be most effective and safe to meet the most important needs in a [[health system]].<!-- <ref name=WHO2017Def/> --> The list is frequently used by countries to help develop their own local lists of [[essential medicine]].<ref name=WHO2017Def>{{cite web|title=Essential medicines|url=http://www.who.int/medicines/services/essmedicines_def/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=19 January 2017}}</ref> As of 2016, more than 155 countries have created national lists of essential medicines based on the World Health Organization's model list.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/medicines/events/fs/en/ |title=The WHO Essential Medicines List (EML): 30th anniversary |publisher=World Health Organization |accessdate=26 June 2016}}</ref> This includes countries in both the [[developed world|developed]] and [[developing world]].<ref name=WHO2017Def/>
<!-- Make up --> The list is divided into core items and complementary items.<!-- <ref name=WHO2015List/> --> The core items are deemed to be the most [[cost effective]] options for key health problems and are usable with little additional health care resources.<!-- <ref name=WHO2015List/> --> The complementary items either require additional infrastructure such as specially trained [[health care providers]] or [[diagnostic equipment]] or have a lower [[cost-benefit ratio]].<ref name=WHO2015List>{{cite web|title=19th WHO Model List of Essential Medicines |date=April 2015|url=http://www.who.int/medicines/publications/essentialmedicines/EML2015_8-May-15.pdf|website=who.int|publisher=World Health Organization|accessdate=17 January 2017|page=Annex 1|format=pdf}}</ref> About 25% of items are in the complementary list.<ref name=Ban2013>{{cite journal|last1=Bansal|first1=D|last2=Purohit|first2=VK|title=Accessibility and use of essential medicines in health care: Current progress and challenges in India.|journal=Journal of Pharmacology & Pharmacotherapeutics|date=January 2013|volume=4|issue=1|pages=13–18|pmid=23662019|doi=10.4103/0976-500X.107642|pmc=3643337}}</ref> Some medications are listed as both core and complementary.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Selection and Use of Essential Medicines - WHO Technical Report Series, No. 920: 5. Reviews of sections of the Model List: 5.2 Review of core versus complementary listing of medicines|url=http://apps.who.int/medicinedocs/en/d/Js4881e/5.2.html|website=apps.who.int|accessdate=6 March 2017|date=2003}}</ref> While most medications on the list are available as [[generic medication|generic products]], being under [[patent]] does not preclude inclusion.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Beall|first1=Reed|title=Patents and the WHO Model List of Essential Medicines (18th Edition): Clarifying the Debate on IP and Access|url=http://www.wipo.int/edocs/mdocs/mdocs/en/wipo_gc_ip_ge_16/wipo_gc_ip_ge_16_brief.pdf|website=WIPO|accessdate=3 May 2017|date=2016}}</ref>
<!-- History --> The first list was published in 1977 and included 212 medications.<ref name=WHO2017Def/><ref name=Lancet2017>{{cite journal|last1=Wirtz|first1=VJ|last2=Hogerzeil|first2=HV|last3=Gray|first3=AL|last4=Bigdeli|first4=M|last5=de Joncheere|first5=CP|last6=Ewen|first6=MA|last7=Gyansa-Lutterodt|first7=M|last8=Jing|first8=S|last9=Luiza|first9=VL|last10=Mbindyo|first10=RM|last11=Möller|first11=H|last12=Moucheraud|first12=C|last13=Pécoul|first13=B|last14=Rägo|first14=L|last15=Rashidian|first15=A|last16=Ross-Degnan|first16=D|last17=Stephens|first17=PN|last18=Teerawattananon|first18=Y|last19='t Hoen|first19=EF|last20=Wagner|first20=AK|last21=Yadav|first21=P|last22=Reich|first22=MR|display-authors=5|title=Essential medicines for universal health coverage|journal=The Lancet|date=28 January 2017|volume=389|issue=10067|pages=403–476|pmid=27832874|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(16)31599-9}}</ref> The WHO updates the list every two years.<ref name=WHO2015Web/> The 14th list was published in 2005 and contained 306 medications.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Prakash|first1=B|last2=Nadig|first2=P|last3=Nayak|first3=A|title=Rational Prescription for a Dermatologist.|journal=Indian Journal of Dermatology|date=2016|volume=61|issue=1|pages=32–38|pmid=26955092|doi=10.4103/0019-5154.174017|pmc=4763692}}</ref> In 2015 the 19th edition of the list was published and contains around 410 medications.<ref name=WHO2015Web>{{cite web|title=WHO Model Lists of Essential Medicines|url=http://www.who.int/medicines/publications/essentialmedicines/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=17 January 2017}}</ref> The 20th edition was published in 2017 and comprises 433 drugs.<ref name=WHO201720th>{{cite web|title=WHO Model List of Essential Medicines 20th List|url=http://www.who.int/medicines/publications/essentialmedicines/20th_EML2017.pdf?ua=1|accessdate=8 June 2017|date=March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Essential Medicines List and WHO Model Formulary|url=http://www.who.int/selection_medicines/list/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=5 May 2018}}</ref> The national lists contain between 334 and 580 medications.<ref name=Ban2013 />
<!-- Society and culture --> A separate list for children up to 12 years of age, known as the [[WHO Model List of Essential Medicines for Children]] (EMLc), was created in 2007 and is in its 6th edition.<ref name=WHO2015Web/><ref>{{cite web|title=WHO Model List of Essential Medicines for Children 6th List|url=http://www.who.int/medicines/publications/essentialmedicines/6th_EMLc2017_FINAL_amendedAug2017.pdf?ua=1|website=who.int|publisher=World Health Organization|accessdate=11 April 2018|date=August 2017}}</ref> It was created to make sure that the needs of children were systematically considered such as availability of proper [[pharmaceutical formulation|formulations]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Rose|first1=K|last2=Anker|first2=JNVd|title=Guide to Paediatric Drug Development and Clinical Research|date=2010|publisher=Karger Medical and Scientific Publishers|isbn=9783805593625|page=42|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=o8bDJPHqGeYC&pg=PA42|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Seyberth|first1=HW|last2=Rane|first2=A|last3=Schwab|first3=M|title=Pediatric Clinical Pharmacology|date=2011|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=9783642201950|page=358|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=jM1gob3MeVYC&pg=PA358|language=en}}</ref> Everything in the children's list is also included in the main list.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kalle|first1=H|title=Essential Medicines for Children|journal=Clinical Pharmacology & Therapeutics|date=9 February 2017|pmid=28182281|doi=10.1002/cpt.661|volume=101|issue=6|pages=718–720}}</ref> The list and notes are based on the 19th and 20th edition of the main list.<ref name=WHO2015List/><ref name=WHO201720th/> An [[Alpha|α]] indicates a medicine is only on the complementary list.<ref name=WHO2015List/> {{TOC limit|3}}
==Anaesthetics==
===General anaesthetics and oxygen===
====Inhalational medicines==== * [[Halothane]] * [[Isoflurane]] * [[Nitrous oxide (medication)|Nitrous oxide]] * [[Oxygen therapy|Oxygen]]
====Injectable medicines==== * [[Ketamine]] * [[Propofol]]<ref name="Thiopental" group="note">[[Thiopental]] may be used as an alternative depending on local availability and cost.</ref>

[[mr:आवश्यक औषधे]]

{{no footnotes|date=March 2013}} The '''William and Katherine Estes Award''', previously known as the '''NAS Award for Behavioral Research Relevant to the Prevention of Nuclear War''' is awarded by the U.S. [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]] "to recognize basic research in any field of cognitive or behavioral science that has employed rigorous formal or empirical methods, optimally a combination of these, to advance our understanding of problems or issues relating to the risk of nuclear war". It was first awarded in 1990. <ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.nasonline.org/programs/awards/behavioral-research.html|title=William and Katherine Estes Award|publisher= National Academy of Sciences|accessdate=10 March 2017}} </ref>
==Recipients==
Source: [http://www.nasonline.org/programs/awards/behavioral-research.html NAS]
[[Scott Sagan|Scott D. Sagan]] (2015) - For his pioneering theoretical and empirical work addressing the risks of nuclear possession and deployment and the causes of nuclear proliferation.
[[Robert Powell (political scientist)|Robert Powell]] (2012) - For sophisticated game theoretic models of conflict that illuminate the heart of the strategic dilemmas of nuclear deterrence, including the importance of private information.
[[Graham Allison]] (2009) - For illuminating alternative ways of thinking about political decision making with special relevance to crises, including nuclear crises, as demonstrated in his groundbreaking ''[[Essence of Decision]]'' and subsequent works.
[[Robert Jervis]] (2006) - For showing, scientifically and in policy terms, how cognitive psychology, politically contextualized, can illuminate strategies for the avoidance of nuclear war.
[[Walter Enders]] and [[Todd Sandler]] (2003) - For their joint work on transnational terrorism using game theory and time series analysis to document the cyclic and shifting nature of terrorist attacks in response to defensive counteractions.
[[Philip E. Tetlock]] (2000) - For successfully developing a semantic measure of cognitive complexity predictive of foreign policy decisions and for applying psychological analysis and knowledge to nuclear policy problems.
[[Alexander L. George]] (1997) - For combining theory with history to elucidate the requirements of deterrence, the limits to coercive diplomacy, and the relationship between force and statecraft.
[[Thomas C. Schelling]] (1993) - For his pioneering work on the logic of military strategy, nuclear war, and arms races, which has profoundly influenced our understanding of this crucial subject.
[[Robert Axelrod]] (1990) - For his imaginative use of game theory, experimentation, and computer simulation to define and test strategies for confrontation and cooperation and other models of social interaction.
